diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect various organs and tissues of the body, causing a wide range of symptoms including fever, arthropathy (joint pain or inflammation), leukopenia (low white blood cell count), pericardial effusion, and proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily affecting joints, this autoimmune disorder can also lead to systemic manifestations such as fever, leukopenia, and pericardial effusions in more severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This is a rare autoimmune disorder that exhibits features of several connective tissue diseases (including SLE and rheumatoid arthritis) and may present with fever, leukopenia, proteinuria, arthropathy, and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infections
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections, such as human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) or parvovirus B19, can cause fever, leukopenia, arthropathy, and in some cases, pericardial effusion and proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.rationale: Though more known for skin thickening, scleroderma can also cause internal organ complications leading to symptoms like arthropathy, renal crisis (proteinuria), and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Adult Still's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This is a rare inflammatory disorder characterized by high fevers, arthritis, and a salmon-colored rash. It can also lead to leukopenia and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.rationale: Certain types of leukemia can lead to leukopenia (due to abnormal white cell production suppressing normal cells), fever, and less commonly, pericardial effusion or proteinuria due to kidney infiltration or associated complications.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.rationale: In its disseminated or extrapulmonary forms, tuberculosis can cause widespread systemic symptoms including fever, leukopenia, and possibly pericardial effusion (in cases of pericardial TB).

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: Some lymphomas may present with fever, leukopenia (from bone marrow infiltration), pericardial effusion (as part of systemic involvement), and occasionally involve kidney damage leading to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis is a multi-system inflammatory disease which can cause fever, leukopenia (though lymphopenia is more common), arthropathy, and rarely, pericardial effusion and proteinuria due to kidney involvement.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (e.g., Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, HIV)
Autoimmune diseases (other than SLE, e.g., Sjögren's syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by acute and chronic inflammation of various tissues of the body.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. In some people, the condition can damage a wide variety of body systems, including the skin, eyes, lungs, heart, and blood vessels.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis of the skin. Common features are joint pain, stiffness, and swelling, which can affect any part of the body and can lead to severe joint damage.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection. Often, it begins with flu-like symptoms, followed by a painful red or purplish rash that spreads and blisters.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.description: A group of rare diseases that involve the hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues — fibers that provide the framework and support for your body.

diagnoses.name: Adult Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that leads to fever, rash, and joint pain. It may lead to chronic arthritis and can affect other organs such as the heart, lungs, and kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's primarily seen in children. The most common symptoms include fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, irritation and redness of the eyes, swollen lymph glands, and irritation and inflammation of the mouth, lips, and throat.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can cause fever, headache, fatigue, and a characteristic skin rash called erythema migrans. If left untreated, infection can spread to joints, the heart, and the nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection transmitted by ticks. It's characterized by a high fever, headache, muscle aches, and, importantly, a rash that includes small, flat pink spots that can eventually spread and merge.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An uncommon inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. The condition can affect adults and children, and its signs and symptoms vary. It's considered a muscular dystrophy.

diagnoses: Neurological Disorders Affecting Swallowing (e.g., Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, Multiple Sclerosis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Familial Thoracic Aortic Aneurysm and Dissection
Acute Cystitis – Given the urinary tract infection symptoms.
Pyelonephritis – If the urinary tract infection symptoms are accompanied by fever and flank pain.
Otitis Externa – Directly correlates with the symptom named.
Chronic Low Back Pain – Specifically related to the chronic back pain symptom.
Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders – Can be linked to decreased immunoglobulins, making patients more susceptible to infections.
Hyperactivity Disorder – Links directly to hyperactivity symptoms, such as ADHD.
Interstitial Cystitis – Chronic condition that can mimic the symptoms of a urinary tract infection.
Chronic Kidney Disease – Decreased immunoglobulins and recurrent urinary tract infections might indicate an underlying condition like CKD.
Fibromyalgia – Can cause chronic pain including back pain and might also be associated with sleep disturbances which lead to hyperactivity symptoms.
Diabetic Neuropathy – Diabetes could lead to UTIs due to immunosuppression, chronic pain due to nerve damage, and decreases in immunoglobulin levels.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS can lead to a weakened immune system, potentially causing leukoplakia, lymphadenopathy, and increased susceptibility to infections such as urinary tract infections. Neurological complications can include difficulty concentrating.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Chronic kidney disease can cause cysts in the kidneys (known as acquired cystic kidney disease), contribute to urinary tract infections due to altered bladder function, and indirectly cause difficulty concentrating due to toxin accumulation in the blood.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: Lupus is an autoimmune disease that can cause leukoplakia, as a result of mouth ulcers, lymphadenopathy, difficulty concentrating due to CNS involvement, and can increase the risk of urinary tract infections due to immunosuppression.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.description: This rare disorder causes blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, leading to symptoms like mouth sores resembling leukoplakia, and can also cause difficulty concentrating when it affects the brain.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease affecting the body's moisture-producing glands. While primarily known for causing dry mouth and eyes, it can also cause leukoplakia due to chronic mouth dryness, lymphadenopathy, and has been associated with neurological symptoms including difficulty concentrating.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that can cause leukoplakia-like lesions in its tertiary stage, lymphadenopathy in its primary and secondary stages, and neurological problems including difficulty concentrating during its tertiary stage (neurosyphilis).

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which can cause lymphadenopathy. While primarily affecting the lungs, it can impact other areas of the body, potentially contributing to systemic symptoms like difficulty concentrating.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the lymph nodes can cause lymphadenopathy and may lead to systemic symptoms such as difficulty concentrating. Depending on the type and location, lymphoma can also cause other symptoms, potentially aligning with those described.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder characterized by the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys that can cause chronic kidney pain and is associated with urinary tract infections due to altered urine flow.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Diabetes can lead to a compromised immune system, raising the risk of urinary tract infections. Additionally, high blood sugar levels can cause a variety of symptoms including difficulty concentrating. It can also influence the development of cysts in organs due to vascular damage over time.

diagnoses: Angioedema as part of an allergic reaction or hereditary angioedema

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reason: This autoimmune disease can present with widespread symptoms, including cognitive disturbances (attention deficits), lymphadenopathy, menstrual irregularities, and increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.reason: Characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells, symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, susceptibility to infections due to compromised immunity, and general symptoms such as fatigue which can impair cognitive function.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.reason: This diverse group of blood cancers shares some presenting symptoms with Hodgkin's Lymphoma, including lymphadenopathy and an increased risk of infections. Though attention deficits and dysmenorrhea are not direct symptoms, systemic disease can impact overall health, leading to a plethora of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reason: The human immunodeficiency virus affects the immune system, leading to an increased susceptibility to infections. Lymphadenopathy is a common early sign. While not directly causing dysmenorrhea, the virus can impact overall health, potentially affecting menstrual cycles and cognitive functions.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: This syndrome is characterized by severe, unexplained fatigue that isn't improved by rest. Patients may also experience cognitive impairments (attention deficits), and immune dysfunction is thought to be a contributing factor, potentially leading to an increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.reason: Anemia can lead to a plethora of symptoms including fatigue and cognitive impairments. Women with heavy menstrual bleeding experience dysmenorrhea and are at risk of iron deficiency, which can also affect the immune system's function.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.reason: This is a rare autoimmune disease affecting small and medium-sized arteries, potentially leading to symptoms across the body, including neuropsychiatric symptoms (cognitive impairments), menstrual irregularities, and an overall state that might increase infection susceptibility.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: In addition to joint pain and damage, rheumatoid arthritis can cause systemic symptoms, including lymphadenopathy. The autoimmune nature of the disease can affect overall health, including menstrual cycles and vulnerability to infections.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reason: An inflammatory disease characterized by granulomas, sarcoidosis can affect multiple organs including the lymph nodes, leading to lymphadenopathy. It can also impair the immune system, increasing infection susceptibility. Attention deficits are not directly caused but could be secondary to systemic illness.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Thyroid Disease (Hashimoto's or Graves')
diagnoses.reason: Both conditions can lead to a wide range of symptoms, including those affecting cognitive function, potentially contributing to attention deficits. They can also impact menstrual cycles and overall immune function, leading to a heightened risk of infections.

diagnoses: Acute Intestinal Infections due to other specified organisms
Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe throbbing and pulsating pain on one side of the head. It is accompanied by visual disturbances (aura), nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include headache, trouble speaking, paralysis or numbness of the face, arm, or leg, and visual problems.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a temporary blockage of blood flow to the brain, causing short-lived symptoms similar to those of a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms may include headache, vomiting, speech difficulties, visual changes, and seizures, depending on the tumor's location.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Specific types of epilepsy can include symptoms like aphasia and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can include headache, fever, vomiting, confusion, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis
diagnoses.description: A rare form of stroke that occurs when a blood clot forms in the brain's venous sinuses. This prevents blood from draining out of the brain, leading to increased intracranial pressure and the potential for headache, vomiting, visual disturbances, and speech difficulty.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms are varied and can include fatigue, difficulty walking, numbness or weakness, muscle spasms, and in some cases, visual disturbances and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Intracerebral hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Occurs when a diseased blood vessel within the brain bursts, allowing blood to leak inside the brain. Symptoms can include a sudden and severe headache, vomiting, weakness in an arm or leg, difficulty speaking, and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain often caused by a viral infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, confusion, vomiting, and in some cases, seizures and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A primary headache disorder characterized by recurrent headaches that are moderate to severe. Symptoms may include phonophobia, nausea, and light sensitivity.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A result of damage to your peripheral nerves, often causes weakness, numbness and pain, usually in your hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes.

diagnoses.name: Cervical Spondylosis
diagnoses.description: Also known as cervical osteoarthritis, involves changes to the bones, discs, and joints of the neck. Symptoms may include pain and stiffness as well as numbness and weakness in the arms, hands, and fingers.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a ministroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to the brain.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes. It most often affects the legs and feet but can also affect other parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes numbness, tingling, or weakness in your hand. It stems from pressure on your median nerve, which runs the length of your arm.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Can lead to nerve damage. Vitamin B12 deficiency is known to cause symptoms of numbness and tingling, muscle weakness, and loss of reflexes.

diagnoses: Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with nonscarring alopecia, leukopenia, and neurological manifestations such as seizures. Proteinuria indicates renal involvement, and chilblains (pernio) can occur in lupus patients, especially in cold environments.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by muscle weakness and distinctive skin rashes, dermatomyositis can also cause nonscarring alopecia. Although less common, renal involvement might lead to proteinuria. Chilblain-like lesions are recognized in association with dermatomyositis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease presents with features of several connective tissue diseases including SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis. It can manifest with leukopenia, nonscarring alopecia, and proteinuria due to renal involvement. Neurological symptoms can include seizures.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primary features include dry eyes and dry mouth, but it can also cause nonscarring alopecia and proteinuria if the kidneys are involved. Neurological involvement can lead to seizures, and leukopenia is a possible hematologic manifestation.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: A connective tissue disease that leads to skin tightening and thickening, systemic sclerosis can also result in nonscarring alopecia and renal crisis, which may present as proteinuria. Peripheral vascular problems can cause chilblains.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting joints, rheumatoid arthritis can have systemic manifestations including leukopenia due to Felty's syndrome, and nonscarring alopecia. Vasculitis can lead to skin symptoms like chilblains.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. It can lead to skin rashes, mouth sores, eye inflammation, and can potentially cause symptoms like nonscarring alopecia, and, less commonly, renal involvement with proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: A specific manifestation of SLE affecting the kidneys, which can lead to proteinuria. While it directly relates to kidney function, systemic lupus erythematosus symptoms may also include nonscarring alopecia, leukopenia, and neurological abnormalities like seizures.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.rationale: This is a type of vasculitis that can affect several organs including the skin, nerves, kidneys, and heart. Symptoms can include hypertension, kidney damage leading to proteinuria, skin lesions resembling chilblains, and neurological manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Cryoglobulinemia
diagnoses.rationale: Associated with hepatitis C, cryoglobulinemia causes blood proteins to clump in cold temperatures, potentially leading to symptoms like chilblains, proteinuria due to renal involvement, and a variety of skin manifestations, including nonscarring alopecia.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
